items.title: Update README
items.body:
`README.md` starts with:

> This is a Python implementation of Macaroons. It is still under active development but is in a useable state - please report any bugs in the issue tracker.

At the same time, last commit was 10 months ago, so "active development" seems a bit off.

Assuming that the project has not been abandoned or put on the back burner, I imagine that "useable state" is not accurate either -- it kinds conveys "can be used for some purposes, but there are large known issues"

I propose that README is updated :)

items.title: py-macaroon-bakery & pymacaroons depend on completely different implementation of nacl
items.body:
py-macaroon-bakery depends on https://github.com/pyca/pynacl/
pymacaroons depends on https://github.com/saltstack/libnacl

Since both are related to each other, it would be nice if they share the same dependency and not completely different implementations

https://github.com/go-macaroon-bakery/py-macaroon-bakery/issues/47

items.title: LICENSE file is missing in 0.12.0 sdist on pypi
items.body:
Current version that's available on pypi (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pymacaroons/0.12.0)  does not include the LICENSE file:

```
$ curl -s https://pypi.python.org/packages/38/a8/f98dfe2aca2301e8b8899166554bde1437c7110579c372581e1225ab0c81/pymacaroons-0.12.0.tar.gz#md5=a3b6cb10bbc4804a199a135b9f04f327 |tar -ztf - |grep LICENSE   
$
```

PS I'm not sure what process is used to build source tarballs, but when I run `python setup.py sdist`, I get all the data files included. When I change `MANIFEST.in` like this:

```
diff --git a/MANIFEST.in b/MANIFEST.in                                                                                                                                                                             
index 431b7b1..7657270 100644                                                                                                                                                                                      
--- a/MANIFEST.in                                                                                                                                                                                                  
+++ b/MANIFEST.in                                                                                                                                                                                                  
@@ -1,6 +1,7 @@                                                                                                                                                                                                    
+exclude *                                                                                                                                                                                                         
 recursive-include docs *                                                                                                                                                                                          
 recursive-exclude docs/_templates *                                                                                                                                                                               
 recursive-exclude docs/_build *                                                                                                                                                                                   
 include *.py                                                                                                                                                                                                      
 include README.md                                                                                                                                                                                                 
-include LICENSE.md                                                                                                                                                                                                
+include LICENSE 
```
things start working as expected.

items.title: mutually recursive discharge macaroons cause infinite recursion
items.body:
The following code causes a RuntimeError exception to be raised due to infinite recursion:

    import pymacaroons
    import base64
    
    m1 = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="", identifier="root-id", key="root-key")
    m1.add_third_party_caveat("bob",  "bob-caveat-root-key", "bob-is-great")
    m2 = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="bob", identifier="bob-is-great", key="bob-caveat-root-key")
    m2.add_third_party_caveat("charlie", "bob-caveat-root-key", "bob-is-great")
    m2 = m1.prepare_for_request(m2)
    pymacaroons.Verifier().verify(m1, "root-key", [m2])

An attacker could use this as a denial-of-service attack.

items.title: verification does not use root macaroon signature in bind
items.body:
In the original macaroons paper, PrepareForRequest binds the signature of all the discharge macaroons to the root macaroon's signature. Pymacaroons does not do that when verifying macaroons more than one level deep - instead it binds the signature of the discharge macaroon to that of its parent. This is different (and incompatible) behaviour from that expected by libmacaroons and the Go macaroons implementation.

The following code demonstrates the issue. It uses both libmacaroons and pymacaroons to demonstrate the incompatibility, but the issue can adequately be demonstrated with pymacaroons alone.

	import pymacaroons
	import base64
	import json
	import macaroons
	
	def testpymacaroons():
	    print('test pymacaroons')
	    # Create a root macaroon with discharge.
	    root = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="", identifier="root-id", key="root-key")
	    root.add_third_party_caveat("bob", "bob-caveat-root-key", "bob-is-great")
	    
	    # Create a discharge macaroon that requires a secondary discharge.
	    discharge1 = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="bob", identifier="bob-is-great", key="bob-caveat-root-key")
	    discharge1.add_third_party_caveat("barbara", "barbara-caveat-root-key", "barbara-is-great")
	    
	    # Create the secondary discharge macaroon.
	    discharge2 = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="barbara", identifier="barbara-is-great", key="barbara-caveat-root-key")
	    
	    # Prepare the discharge macaroons for request.
	    discharge1 = root.prepare_for_request(discharge1)
	    discharge2 = root.prepare_for_request(discharge2)
	    
	    # verification fails with MacaroonInvalidSignatureException.
	    try:
	        pymacaroons.Verifier().verify(root, "root-key", [discharge1, discharge2])
	        print('pymacaroons verifed ok')
	    except Exception as e:
	        print('pymacaroons verification failed: {}'.format(e))

	    # libmacaroons succeeds in verifying the same
	    # macaroons that pymacaroons failed on.
	    l_root = macaroons.deserialize(bytes(root.serialize()))
	    l_discharge1 = macaroons.deserialize(bytes(discharge1.serialize()))
	    l_discharge2 = macaroons.deserialize(bytes(discharge2.serialize()))
	
	    try:
	        macaroons.Verifier().verify(l_root, "root-key", [l_discharge1, l_discharge2])
	        print('libmacaroons verified ok after deserialization')
	    except Exception as e:
	        print('libmacaroons verification failed: {}'.format(e))
	
	def testlibmacaroons():
	    print('test libmacaroons')
	    # Create a root macaroon with discharge.
	    root = macaroons.create("", "root-key", "root-id")
	    root = root.add_third_party_caveat("bob", "bob-caveat-root-key", "bob-is-great")
	    
	    # Create a discharge macaroon that requires a secondary discharge.
	    discharge1 = macaroons.create("bob", "bob-caveat-root-key", "bob-is-great")
	    discharge1 = discharge1.add_third_party_caveat("babara", "barbara-caveat-root-key", "barbara-is-great")
	    
	    # Create the secondary discharge macaroon.
	    discharge2 = macaroons.create("barbara", "barbara-caveat-root-key", "barbara-is-great")
	    
	    # Prepare the discharge macaroons for request.
	    discharge1 = root.prepare_for_request(discharge1)
	    discharge2 = root.prepare_for_request(discharge2)

	    # verification succeeds ok.
	    macaroons.Verifier().verify(root, "root-key", [discharge1, discharge2])
	    
	    print('libmacaroons verified ok')

	    # pymacaroons fails to verify the macaroons that libmacaroons succeeded
	    # in verifying
	    p_root = pymacaroons.Macaroon.deserialize(root.serialize(format=1))
	    p_discharge1 = pymacaroons.Macaroon.deserialize(discharge1.serialize(format=1))
	    p_discharge2 = pymacaroons.Macaroon.deserialize(discharge2.serialize(format=1))
	
	    try:
	        pymacaroons.Verifier().verify(p_root, "root-key", [p_discharge1, p_discharge2])
	        print('pymacaroons verified ok after deserialization')
	    except Exception as e:
	        print('pymacaroons verification failed: {}'.format(e))
	
	testpymacaroons()
	testlibmacaroons()

items.title: Switch to pynacl

milestone.description: This release makes v2 format the default and requires explicit opt-in for v1 support.

items.body:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/PyNaCl/

PyNaCl is a different binding to libsodium which bundles libsodium as well. This would make installation significantly simpler (can still bring your own libsodium if you need to)

items.title: Fix pypy3 on travis

milestone.description: 0.11.0 supports both v1 macaroons (the kind supported by <= 0.10.0) as well as v2. The primary difference is that v2 macaroon fields are variable length.

items.body:
Currently failing with:

```
pip requires Python '>=2.6,!=3.0.*,!=3.1.*,!=3.2.*' but the running Python is 3.2.5
```

The latest versions of pip that travis installs don't support the version of python that `pypy3` acts as in tox.

items.title: json deserialize raises an exception on missing vid or cl

milestone.description: 0.11.0 supports both v1 macaroons (the kind supported by <= 0.10.0) as well as v2. The primary difference is that v2 macaroon fields are variable length.

items.body:
The vid and cl fields are optional in the JSON macaroon format, but
JsonSerializer.deserialize raises a missing key exception
if a caveat doesn't have them.

Probably the code should be:

    verification_key_id=(
                    standard_b64decode(c['vid']) if c.get('vid') else None
                ),

(using `c.get('vid')` rather than `c['vid']`)

milestone.description: 0.11.0 supports both v1 macaroons (the kind supported by <= 0.10.0) as well as v2. The primary difference is that v2 macaroon fields are variable length.

items.title: Superfluous upper bound on libnacl?
items.body: pymacaroons declares `libnacl>=1.3.6,<1.4` in `install_requires`, but the functional tests seem to pass just fine with libnacl 1.4.5.  Is the upper bound here superfluous, or can it at least be bumped?  I don't see anything in the changes for libnacl 1.4.0 that would indicate a compatibility break.

items.title: It doesn't work on Ubuntu Xenial
items.body:
It looks like because it's depending on `libnacl<1.4,>=1.3.6`, which in turns fails to install with `OSError: Could not locate nacl lib, searched for libsodium.so, libsodium.so.13, libsodium.so.10, libsodium.so.5, libsodium.so.4,  and tweetnacl.so`.

However, libsodium _is_ installed in the system, but version 18.

Note that pip installs correctly libnacl v1.4.4, so the problem is in the "<1.4" restriction as I noted above.

BTW, all this is under Python 3.5.

Any help with debugging or any question, just tell me.

Thanks!!

items.title: Accept either bytes or string when deserializing
items.body:
If a token is a bytes object, deserializing throws an unhelpful error: 

``` python
>>> Macaroon.deserialize(token)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/pymacaroons/macaroon.py", line 40, in deserialize
    return serializer.deserialize(serialized)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/pymacaroons/serializers/binary_serializer.py", line 42, in deserialize
    serialized + "=" * (-len(serialized) % 4)
TypeError: can't concat bytes to str
```

Instead, it should accept either bytes or a string.

items.title: Crashes while doing .inspect()
items.body:
See:

```
Python 3.4.3+ (default, Oct 14 2015, 16:03:50) 
[GCC 5.2.1 20151010] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import pymacaroons
>>> pymacaroons.__version__
'0.9.0'
>>> m = pymacaroons.Macaroon(location="location", identifier="identifier", key="key")
>>> m.add_third_party_caveat("other location", "caveat key", "identifier")
<pymacaroons.macaroon.Macaroon object at 0x7ff9474fc978>
>>> m.inspect()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/facundo/.local/share/fades/664c588e-be8a-4843-8e95-dfdba5a36353/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pymacaroons/macaroon.py", line 85, in inspect
    if caveat.verification_key_id and caveat.location:
  File "/home/facundo/.local/share/fades/664c588e-be8a-4843-8e95-dfdba5a36353/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pymacaroons/caveat.py", line 22, in verification_key_id
    return convert_to_string(self._verification_key_id)
  File "/home/facundo/.local/share/fades/664c588e-be8a-4843-8e95-dfdba5a36353/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pymacaroons/utils.py", line 25, in convert_to_string
    return string_or_bytes.decode('ascii')
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x89 in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)
```

items.title: README.md comments on satisfy_general seems wrong
items.body:
The comments around satisfy_general say:

``` python
# General caveats are verified by arbitrary functions
# that return false if the caveat is not met
# and true if it is met or not understood
```

The statement `and true if it is met or not understood` does not seem to match the implementation. The implementation is such that it should return False if not understood. As implemented, If any satisfy_general callback returns True the macaroon is valid.

Example code:

``` python
from pymacaroons import Macaroon, Verifier

def foo(predicate):
    print("foo", predicate)
    return True

def bar(predicate):
    print("bar", predicate)
    return False

m = Macaroon(key='key', location='location', identifier='identifier')

m.add_first_party_caveat('key1 = value1')
m.add_first_party_caveat('key2 = value2')

v = Verifier()
v.satisfy_general(foo)
v.satisfy_general(bar)

try:
    print(v.verify(m, 'key'))
except Exception as e:
    print(e)
```

Even though bar returns False, the macaroon is "valid" since foo returns True, which is expected according to the implementation but goes against the comment.

The implementation currently matches libmacaroons python bindings as well.

So I think the comment just needs to be updated to say to return True if the predicate is both understood and met, otherwise false.

items.title: Import at the same time as libmacaroons?
items.body:
I'm making a library that tests compatibility between different
macaroons implementations [1]. To this end, I would like to be able to import
both pymacaroons and the libmacaroons python library at the same
time. Unfortunately they both use the "macaroons" identifier.
Is there any way to work around this?

[1] https://github.com/go-macaroon/macarooncompat

items.title: Use tox to test multiple pythons locally
items.body: Right now we're only testing multiple python versions with Travis. Using tox would allow that to be tested locally as well.
